text:
For example, if you’ve ever:

• Simulated matching a bet against an order book
• Calculated an implied probability from the market
• Used any kind of trading signal based on volumes available

Then you’ve been influenced by cross matching

elements.text: For example, if you’ve ever:
Simulated matching a bet against an order book
Calculated an implied probability from the market
Used any kind of trading signal based on volumes available
Then you’ve been influenced by cross matching

• You’re seeing more available liquidity than has actually been posted

text: The difference between having XM on and off is very subtle in stable markets, often it is just the amount at the price that is different. This can have a slightly -ve effect (ie if you see a price at 10.5 and lay £10 at 11 you may only get £2 matched at 10.5 and £8 at 11 etc, here is a video i did 10 years or so ago which shows a single market with XM on and adjacent XM off. If you pause the video at points you can see the differences. <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3njy483sL-w> it helped me fall asleep many times over the years thinking how to get the best out of it :grinning:

attachments.title: Xm V No XM
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Xm V No XM
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/3njy483sL-w?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

text: The volume in-play per point in tennis is very large (for most matches). I calculate the average price per takeout (price x size) and use that as a price guide. If I start running out of availability I will be earning more than enough to never worry about it :wink:

elements.text: The volume in-play per point in tennis is very large (for most matches). I calculate the average price per takeout (price x size) and use that as a price guide. If I start running out of availability I will be earning more than enough to never worry about it
